clusters.title: One of 2 National Guard members shot in D.C. has died, Trump says
clusters.neutral_headline: National Guard Member Dies After Shooting in Washington DC

items.title: One of 2 National Guard members shot in D.C. has died, Trump says
items.standfirst: Two members of the West Virginia National Guard were shot a few blocks from the White House on Wednesday, and a suspect identified as an Afghan national is in custody.
items.content: Two members of the West Virginia National Guard were shot a few blocks from the White House on Wednesday, and a suspect identified as an Afghan national is in custody.

items.title: Trump admin. sending 500 more Guard troops to D.C. after shooting, Hegseth says
items.standfirst: The Trump administration plans to deploy another 500 members of the National Guard to the streets of Washington, D.C., Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced, hours after two service members were shot.
items.content: The Trump administration plans to deploy another 500 members of the National Guard to the streets of Washington, D.C., Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced, hours after two service members were shot.

items.title: Trump admin. pauses immigration applications from Afghans after National Guard shooting
items.standfirst: Federal immigration authorities said Wednesday they have paused processing requests from Afghan nationals, after a man from Afghanistan was identified as the suspect in the D.C. National Guard shooting.
items.content: Federal immigration authorities said Wednesday they have paused processing requests from Afghan nationals, after a man from Afghanistan was identified as the suspect in the D.C. National Guard shooting.

items.title: Second National Guard member shot in D.C. is "fighting for his life," Trump says

items.content: President Trump told reporters Thursday evening that 20-year-old Army Spc. Sarah Beckstrom died from her injuries in the Washington, D.C., shooting.

items.title: One of the National Guard troops shot in D.C. attack has died, Trump says
items.standfirst: President Trump told reporters Thursday night that Army Spc. Sarah Beckstrom has died. Beckstrom was one of the National Guard troops shot in Wednesday's Washington, D.C., ambush attack. Andrew Wolfe, the other victim, is still in critical condition. CBS News' Nicole Sganga reports.
items.content: President Trump told reporters Thursday night that Army Spc. Sarah Beckstrom has died. Beckstrom was one of the National Guard troops shot in Wednesday's Washington, D.C., ambush attack. Andrew Wolfe, the other victim, is still in critical condition. CBS News' Nicole Sganga reports.

items.title: Trump officials announce sweeping immigration reviews after national guard shooting
items.standfirst: Donald Trump signaled after attack that refugee and asylum cases would be scrutinizedTrump administration officials say they are undertaking a broad re-examination of asylum cases and green cards issued to citizens of certain countries, after the shooting of two national guard members near the White House in Washington DC on Wednesday.The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) named the suspect in the shooting as Rahmanullah Lakanwal, a 29-year-old Afghan national who entered the US under a policy set up under Joe Biden after the US withdrawal from Afghanistan in 2021 and continued under Donald Trump. Continue reading...
items.content: Donald Trump signaled after attack that refugee and asylum cases would be scrutinizedTrump administration officials say they are undertaking a broad re-examination of asylum cases and green cards issued to citizens of certain countries, after the shooting of two national guard members near the White House in Washington DC on Wednesday.The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) named the suspect in the shooting as Rahmanullah Lakanwal, a 29-year-old Afghan national who entered the US under a policy set up under Joe Biden after the US withdrawal from Afghanistan in 2021 and continued under Donald Trump. Continue reading...

items.title: National Guard's Sarah Beckstrom dies following shooting near White House
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump said on Thursday that National Guard soldier Sarah Beckstrom, one of two troops shot near the White House a day earlier, had died, while the other remained “fighting for his life.” Trump called Beckstrom a “highly respected, young, magnificent person.”
items.content: President Donald Trump said on Thursday that National Guard soldier Sarah Beckstrom, one of two troops shot near the White House a day earlier, had died, while the other remained “fighting for his life.” Trump called Beckstrom a “highly respected, young, magnificent person.”

items.title: Suspect in Washington DC national guard shooting had ties to CIA, agency confirms
items.standfirst: Rahmanullah Lakanwal, 29, worked with agency-backed military units during US war in AfghanistanWashington DC national guard shooting: what we know so farThe suspected shooter of two national guard members in Washington DC on Wednesday worked with CIA-backed military units during the US war in Afghanistan, the agency has confirmed.The alleged gunman, identified as Rahmanullah Lakanwal, 29, came to the US in September 2021 under an Operation Allies Welcome program that gave some Afghans who had worked for the US government entry visas to the US. He was granted asylum in April this year, under the Trump administration, Reuters reported. Continue reading...
items.content: Rahmanullah Lakanwal, 29, worked with agency-backed military units during US war in AfghanistanWashington DC national guard shooting: what we know so farThe suspected shooter of two national guard members in Washington DC on Wednesday worked with CIA-backed military units during the US war in Afghanistan, the agency has confirmed.The alleged gunman, identified as Rahmanullah Lakanwal, 29, came to the US in September 2021 under an Operation Allies Welcome program that gave some Afghans who had worked for the US government entry visas to the US. He was granted asylum in April this year, under the Trump administration, Reuters reported. Continue reading...

items.title: US reviewing 'every' Green Card from 19 countries after capital attack
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump ordered a sweeping review of US green card holders from what his administration calls “countries of concern,” the head of US Citizenship and Immigration Services said on Thursday, directing the agency to reassess vetting procedures for permanent residents from those nations.
items.content: President Donald Trump ordered a sweeping review of US green card holders from what his administration calls “countries of concern,” the head of US Citizenship and Immigration Services said on Thursday, directing the agency to reassess vetting procedures for permanent residents from those nations.

The big picture: Trump vowed to step up his administration's hardline…

items.title: What was 'Operation Allies Welcome,' which allowed some Afghans entry into the U.S.?
items.standfirst: The Afghan man suspected of shooting two National Guard members entered the U.S. under the program in 2021. Here's a look at why it was set up and how those who entered the U.S. were vetted.
items.content: The Afghan man suspected of shooting two National Guard members entered the U.S. under the program in 2021. Here's a look at why it was set up and how those who entered the U.S. were vetted.(Image credit: Anthony Peltier)

items.title: National Guard shooting suspect served in CIA counterterrorism unit, group says
items.standfirst: Rahmanullah Lakanwal, the Afghan man who allegedly shot two National Guard members in Washington, D.C., had served in one of Afghanistan's elite counterterrorism units, according to a nonprofit run by people who served in Afghanistan.
items.content: Rahmanullah Lakanwal, the Afghan man who allegedly shot two National Guard members in Washington, D.C., had served in one of Afghanistan's elite counterterrorism units, according to a nonprofit run by people who served in Afghanistan.(Image credit: U.S. Attorney’s Office)

items.title: Latest news on Afghan suspect accused of ambushing 2 National Guard members in D.C.
items.standfirst: Officials announced that Rahmanullah Lakanwal, an Afghan national who entered the U.S. in 2021 and once worked with the U.S. government, including the CIA, is suspected of carrying out a "calculated attack" against two National Guard members in Washington, D.C., on Wednesday. CBS News' Nicole Sganga, Nancy Cordes and Sam Vinograd have more.
items.content: Officials announced that Rahmanullah Lakanwal, an Afghan national who entered the U.S. in 2021 and once worked with the U.S. government, including the CIA, is suspected of carrying out a "calculated attack" against two National Guard members in Washington, D.C., on Wednesday. CBS News' Nicole Sganga, Nancy Cordes and Sam Vinograd have more.

items.title: Trump reacts to National Guard shooting in D.C. as details emerge about Afghan suspect
items.standfirst: President Trump weighed in on the shooting in Washington, D.C., where two members of the National Guard were injured. The suspect, Rahmanullah Lakanwal, an Afghan national who entered the U.S. in 2021, previously worked with the U.S. government, including the CIA, CBS News has learned. Nancy Cordes and Sam Vinograd have more.
items.content: President Trump weighed in on the shooting in Washington, D.C., where two members of the National Guard were injured. The suspect, Rahmanullah Lakanwal, an Afghan national who entered the U.S. in 2021, previously worked with the U.S. government, including the CIA, CBS News has learned. Nancy Cordes and Sam Vinograd have more.

items.title: 2 National Guard members in critical condition after "ambush" attack linked to Afghan national
items.standfirst: Officials provided an update on the investigation into a shooting in Washington, D.C., where two National Guard members were allegedly targeted by 29-year-old Afghan national Rahmanullah Lakanwal. The suspect faces several charges of assault with intent to kill while armed. CBS News' Nicole Sganga reports.
items.content: Officials provided an update on the investigation into a shooting in Washington, D.C., where two National Guard members were allegedly targeted by 29-year-old Afghan national Rahmanullah Lakanwal. The suspect faces several charges of assault with intent to kill while armed. CBS News' Nicole Sganga reports.

items.content: Sarah Beckstrom and Andrew Wolfe were wounded in the shooting, which the FBI is investigating as 'terrorism'.

items.title: Suspect in Washington DC shooting who 'worked with CIA in Afghanistan' pictured

items.content: A man suspected of opening fire on two members of the National Guard a few streets from the White House is an Afghan national who worked with a CIA-backed unit in Afghanistan, according to officials.

items.title: National Guard member Sarah Beckstrom has died from injuries after D.C. shooting
items.standfirst: Beckstrom, 20, was an Army specialist from Summersville, W.Va. She entered the service in 2023. President Trump said the second Guard member who was shot, Andrew Wolfe, "is fighting for his life."
items.content: Beckstrom, 20, was an Army specialist from Summersville, W.Va. She entered the service in 2023. President Trump said the second Guard member who was shot, Andrew Wolfe, "is fighting for his life."(Image credit: U.S. Attorney’s Office)

items.content: The two soldiers are in critical condition after being attacked blocks from the White House in Washington DC.

ai_summary: A National Guard member, Sarah Beckstrom, died from injuries sustained in a shooting near the White House.
A second National Guard member remains in critical condition following the shooting incident.
President Trump stated the shooting was a "terrorist attack" and criticized the Biden administration.
The suspect in the shooting, identified as an Afghan national, is in custody.
The Trump administration paused immigration applications from Afghan nationals after the shooting.

items.content: Dozens of people have died and hundreds remain unaccounted for after Wednesday's blaze.

items.title: Anger swelling in Hong Kong over deadliest fire in more than 70 years
items.standfirst: Some think leader John Lee’s focus on blaming bamboo scaffolding deflects from actual causeThe inferno that engulfed Wang Fuk Court residential compound in Hong Kong is still burning, but questions are already being asked about what the deadliest fire in more than 70 years means for Beijing’s grip on power in the city.The death toll from the blaze, which tore apart seven of the eight high-rise apartment buildings in Wang Fuk Court, a residential compound home to 4,800 people, is still rising. Hundreds of people are still missing. Continue reading...
items.content: Some think leader John Lee’s focus on blaming bamboo scaffolding deflects from actual causeThe inferno that engulfed Wang Fuk Court residential compound in Hong Kong is still burning, but questions are already being asked about what the deadliest fire in more than 70 years means for Beijing’s grip on power in the city.The death toll from the blaze, which tore apart seven of the eight high-rise apartment buildings in Wang Fuk Court, a residential compound home to 4,800 people, is still rising. items.content: Hong Kong police have arrested three people after a massive fire tore through a high-rise housing complex, leaving at least 83 people dead in the city’s deadliest blaze in three decades.

ai_summary: A fire in a Hong Kong high-rise apartment complex resulted in at least 94 deaths.

Three construction workers have been arrested in connection to the fire.
Public anger has increased due to the city's housing crisis and the fire.
Authorities are investigating the construction company involved in the renovation work.

items.title: Israeli troops kill two Palestinians after they appear to surrender
items.standfirst: The Palestinian Authority says the killings are a "war crime", while an Israeli minister backed the soldiers.
items.content: The Palestinian Authority says the killings are a "war crime", while an Israeli minister backed the soldiers.

items.title: Palestinian Authority accuses Israel of 'war crime' after summary 'execution' in West Bank
items.standfirst: Israeli soldiers on Thursday appeared to kill a pair of Palestinian men in the occupied West Bank after they had surrendered to troops, drawing Palestinian accusations that the men were executed “in cold blood.” The Israeli military said it was investigating. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.
items.content: Israeli soldiers on Thursday appeared to kill a pair of Palestinian men in the occupied West Bank after they had surrendered to troops, drawing Palestinian accusations that the men were executed “in cold blood.” The Israeli military said it was investigating. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky reports from Jerusalem.

items.title: Israeli soldiers appear to kill Palestinian men in West Bank after they surrender
items.standfirst: The Israeli military said it was investigating. The killings, captured in a pair of videos shown on two Arab TV stations, came as Israel pressed ahead with its latest offensive in the West Bank, where the army has stepped up its activities over the past two years.
items.content: The Israeli military said it was investigating. The killings, captured in a pair of videos shown on two Arab TV stations, came as Israel pressed ahead with its latest offensive in the West Bank, where the army has stepped up its activities over the past two years.

items.content: Two Palestinian men were shot dead during an Israeli raid in Jenin on Thursday moments after appearing to surrender, prompting condemnations as footage of the incident sparked widespread outrage.

ai_summary: Two Palestinian men were killed by Israeli forces in the West Bank after appearing to surrender.
The Palestinian Authority condemned the killings as a "war crime."
Israeli military stated it is investigating the incident, captured in videos.
Israeli National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir backed the forces involved in the killings.
The killings occurred during an Israeli offensive in the West Bank.

clusters.title: Guinea-Bissau president arrives in Senegal after coup
clusters.neutral_headline: Guinea-Bissau President Ousted in Military Coup

items.title: Guinea-Bissau president arrives in Senegal after coup
items.standfirst: Guinea-Bissau's ousted president Umaro Sissoco Embalo (pictured) landed in Senegal after being removed from power in a military coup, Senegal's foreign ministry announced. Embalo arrived &quo...
items.content: Guinea-Bissau's ousted president Umaro Sissoco Embalo (pictured) landed in Senegal after being removed from power in a military coup, Senegal's foreign ministry announced. Embalo arrived &quo...

items.title: Guinea-Bissau’s deposed President Embalo arrives in Senegal after coup
items.standfirst: Senegal's Foreign Ministry says Umaro Sissoco Embalo arrived in the country a day after he was deposed in military coup.
items.content: Senegal's Foreign Ministry says Umaro Sissoco Embalo arrived in the country a day after he was deposed in military coup.

items.title: G.Bissau president leaves the country after coup
items.standfirst: In tonight's edition, ousted Guinea-Bissau president Umaro Sissoco Embalo has arrived in Senegal after General Horta N’Tam was appointed as the country’s transitional leader. Also, many women in Africa were promised jobs in hospitality and catering. Instead, they found themselves building drones for the Russian war effort. And in Kinshasa, entire neighbourhoods submerged, streets turned into rivers, flooding fueled not just by heavy rains but by mountains of plastic waste.
items.content: In tonight's edition, ousted Guinea-Bissau president Umaro Sissoco Embalo has arrived in Senegal after General Horta N’Tam was appointed as the country’s transitional leader. Also, many women in Africa were promised jobs in hospitality and catering. Instead, they found themselves building drones for the Russian war effort. And in Kinshasa, entire neighbourhoods submerged, streets turned into rivers, flooding fueled not just by heavy rains but by mountains of plastic waste.

items.title: Ousted Guinea-Bissau President Embalo arrives in Senegal amid regional tensions
items.standfirst: Ousted Guinea-Bissau President Umaro Sissoco Embalo arrived in Senegal on Thursday on a special flight after West Africa’s ECOWAS chair intervened to secure his transfer, Senegal’s foreign ministry said.
items.content: Ousted Guinea-Bissau President Umaro Sissoco Embalo arrived in Senegal on Thursday on a special flight after West Africa’s ECOWAS chair intervened to secure his transfer, Senegal’s foreign ministry said.

items.title: Guinea-Bissau, a day after the military coup
items.standfirst: A day after the military seized power in Guinea-Bissau, General N’Tal was sworn in as interim president during a brief ceremony surrounded by heavily armed soldiers. Once considered a close ally of ousted President Umaro Sissoco Embaló, N’Tal now heads what the army describes as a new command, following Embaló’s arrest and detention.
items.content: A day after the military seized power in Guinea-Bissau, General N’Tal was sworn in as interim president during a brief ceremony surrounded by heavily armed soldiers. Once considered a close ally of ousted President Umaro Sissoco Embaló, N’Tal now heads what the army describes as a new command, following Embaló’s arrest and detention.

items.title: General named new Guinea-Bissau leader a day after coup
items.standfirst: Gen Horta N’Tam is sworn in during a ceremony at the army headquarters.
items.content: Gen Horta N’Tam is sworn in during a ceremony at the army headquarters.

items.title: Guinea-Bissau: General N'Tam named interim president after coup
items.standfirst: General N’Tam was sworn in as Guinea-Bissau’s interim president during a brief ceremony guarded by heavily armed soldiers, a day after the coup that ousted President Umaro Sissoco Embaló. N’Tal, believed to have been a close ally of Embaló, now leads what the military calls a new command, after the former president was arrested and detained. With institutions suspended and events unfolding rapidly following recent elections, the country is facing a highly unstable and fast-moving political situation, as FRANCE 24's Caitlin Kelly explains.
items.content: General N’Tam was sworn in as Guinea-Bissau’s interim president during a brief ceremony guarded by heavily armed soldiers, a day after the coup that ousted President Umaro Sissoco Embaló. N’Tal, believed to have been a close ally of Embaló, now leads what the military calls a new command, after the former president was arrested and detained. With institutions suspended and events unfolding rapidly following recent elections, the country is facing a highly unstable and fast-moving political situation, as FRANCE 24's Caitlin Kelly explains.

ai_summary: Guinea-Bissau's ousted president, Umaro Sissoco Embalo, arrived in Senegal after a coup.
General Horta N’Tam was appointed as the country’s interim leader.
The coup has led to regional tensions and intervention from ECOWAS.
General N’Tam was sworn in as interim president in a ceremony.
The military seized power and arrested the former president.

items.standfirst: Macron says plan to introduce 10 months’ service among 18- and 19-year-olds will help France respond to ‘accelerating threats’France is to introduce voluntary military service of 10 months aimed mainly at young people aged 18 and 19, as concern grows in Europe about the threat from Russia.In a speech to troops in Varces-Allières-et-Risset in the French Alps, the French president, Emmanuel Macron, said the service would begin by mid-2026 and help France respond to “accelerating threats” on the global stage. Continue reading...

items.title: Louvre hikes ticket price by 45% for most non-EU tourists in revenue push
items.standfirst: Paris’s Louvre museum said on Thursday it will raise ticket prices for most non-EU visitors, requiring tourists from the United States, Britain and China to pay $37. The 45% increase is expected to lift annual revenue by up to $23 million to fund structural upgrades after last month’s daylight theft.
items.content: Paris’s Louvre museum said on Thursday it will raise ticket prices for most non-EU visitors, requiring tourists from the United States, Britain and China to pay $37. The 45% increase is expected to lift annual revenue by up to $23 million to fund structural upgrades after last month’s daylight theft.

items.title: Most non-EU visitors will pay 45% more to visit Louvre
items.standfirst: Paris's Louvre museum said Thursday it would raise ticket prices for most non-EU visitors, meaning US, British and Chinese tourists among others will have to pay $37 to get in. The museum told AFP the 45-percent price hike aims to boost annual revenues by up to $23 million to fund structural improvements at the world's most-visited art museum, which is reeling from the daylight theft of priceless treasures last month.
items.content: Paris's Louvre museum said Thursday it would raise ticket prices for most non-EU visitors, meaning US, British and Chinese tourists among others will have to pay $37 to get in. The museum told AFP the 45-percent price hike aims to boost annual revenues by up to $23 million to fund structural improvements at the world's most-visited art museum, which is reeling from the daylight theft of priceless treasures last month.

The increase aims to raise up to $23 million for structural improvements.
The museum is funding upgrades after a daylight theft.

clusters.neutral_headline: Lebanon-Israel: One year into the fragile ceasefire

items.title: Lebanon-Israel: One year into the fragile ceasefire
items.standfirst: A year ago, Israel and Lebanon agreed to a ceasefire after several weeks of intense fighting, triggered in part by the so-called 'pager attack' involving Hezbollah members. The ceasefire has been in effect for a year, but Israel continues to regularly strike southern Lebanon, making daily life extremely difficult for residents. Rawad Taha has the details from Beirut.
items.content: A year ago, Israel and Lebanon agreed to a ceasefire after several weeks of intense fighting, triggered in part by the so-called 'pager attack' involving Hezbollah members. The ceasefire has been in effect for a year, but Israel continues to regularly strike southern Lebanon, making daily life extremely difficult for residents. Rawad Taha has the details from Beirut.

items.title: Year after ceasefire, peace eludes south Lebanon as Israeli strikes continue
items.standfirst: A year on from a ceasefire in Lebanon, Israel is continuing attacks on what it says are Hezbollah's efforts to recover from their war.
items.content: A year on from a ceasefire in Lebanon, Israel is continuing attacks on what it says are Hezbollah's efforts to recover from their war.

ai_summary: A ceasefire between Israel and Lebanon has lasted a year.
The ceasefire followed weeks of intense fighting.
The fighting was triggered by the 'pager attack'.
Israel continues to strike southern Lebanon.
Israeli strikes make daily life difficult for residents.

clusters.title: South Africa hits back after Trump says US won't invite it for G20 next year
clusters.neutral_headline: South Africa hits back after Trump says US won't invite it for G20 next year

items.title: South Africa hits back after Trump says US won't invite it for G20 next year
items.standfirst: The US boycotted the G20 summit in Johannesburg over widely discredited claims of persecution of the white minority.
items.content: The US boycotted the G20 summit in Johannesburg over widely discredited claims of persecution of the white minority.

items.title: Trump says South African officials won't be invited to attend G20 summit in the U.S. next year
items.standfirst: The president's announcement on Truth Social Wednesday included baseless claims of a "white genocide" against Afrikaners in South Africa.
items.content: The president's announcement on Truth Social Wednesday included baseless claims of a "white genocide" against Afrikaners in South Africa.

ai_summary: Trump said the US won't invite South Africa to the G20.
The announcement was made on Truth Social.
Trump made claims of "white genocide" in South Africa.
The US boycotted a G20 summit in Johannesburg.
The boycott was over claims of persecution.
